natural problem:
The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$
natural solution: The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.

Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.

The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.

Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.

In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.

(b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines V_def: "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 - \<i>)}"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h1 : "P = (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j)"
and h2 : "P = - 1"
shows  "233 = a + b + p"
where "a \<in> \<nat>" "b \<in> \<nat>" "p \<in> \<nat>" "prime p" "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines V_def: "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 - \<i>)}"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h1 : "P = (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j)"
and h2 : "P = - 1"
shows  "233 = a + b + p"
where "a \<in> \<nat>" "b \<in> \<nat>" "p \<in> \<nat>" "prime p" "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose there is a set $V$ that contains the six complex numbers $\sqrt 2 i, -\sqrt 2 i, \frac{1+\i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{-1+\i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{1-\i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{-1-\i}{\sqrt 8}$. There is a sequence of 12 complex numbers $z_1, z_2, \ldots, z_{12}$ such that each $z_j$ belongs to $V$ for $1 \leq j \leq 12$. Let $P$ be the product of all $z_j$ for $1 \leq j \leq 12$, and suppose that $P = -1$. Find three natural numbers $a, b, p$ such that $a + b + p = 233$, $p$ is a prime number and $a$ is not divisible by $p$.

a_1.formal problem: Unfortunately, it's not possible to directly translate this problem into an Isabelle language version as it involves probabilistic concepts and statistical calculations. Isabelle is a logical proof assistant and it doesn't support probabilistic reasoning and statistical calculations directly. However, the problem can be solved through statistical or probabilistic programming languages such as R, Python, etc.
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and P z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j=1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "prob {P = -1} = a / p^b"
and h4 : "prime p"
and h5 : "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and P z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j=1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "prob {P = -1} = a / p^b"
and h4 : "prime p"
and h5 : "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a set $V$ that contains the complex numbers $\sqrt{2}i, -\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i), \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i), \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i), \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i)$. Assume that for each number $j$ between 1 and 12 inclusive, $z(j)$ is a member of $V$. Let $P$ be the product of all $z(j)$ for $j$ from 1 to 12. The probability that $P=-1$ is given by $\frac{a}{p^b}$, where $p$ is a prime number and $a$ is not divisible by $p$. Find the sum of $a$, $b$, and $p$. The final answer is $233$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and P z :: "complex"
defines "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 - \<i>)}"
and "P \<equiv> prod (\<lambda> j. z j) {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h1 : "P = - 1"
shows  "let (a, (p, b)) = (1, (2, 115)) in a \<notin> p dvd \<and> prime p \<longrightarrow> a + b + p = 233"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and P z :: "complex"
defines "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (- 1 - \<i>)}"
and "P \<equiv> prod (\<lambda> j. z j) {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h1 : "P = - 1"
shows  "let (a, (p, b)) = (1, (2, 115)) in a \<notin> p dvd \<and> prime p \<longrightarrow> a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: For a set V containing complex numbers $\sqrt 2 * i, - \sqrt 2 * i, \frac{1 + i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{- 1 + i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{1 - i}{\sqrt 8}, \frac{- 1 - i}{\sqrt 8}$, and a product P of the twelve complex numbers $z_j$ for $1 \leq j \leq 12$ with each $z_j$ belonging to V, if P equals -1, then for the tuple (a, (p, b)) equals (1, (2, 115)), if p is a prime number that does not divide a, then a + b + p equals 233.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines "P \<equiv> prod z {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 
                   1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>),
                   1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = -1"
shows  "233 = (card (A \<inter> {n. P = -1})) / card A"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines "P \<equiv> prod z {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 
                   1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>),
                   1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = -1"
shows  "233 = (card (A \<inter> {n. P = -1})) / card A"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Consider a set $V$ containing six complex numbers: $\sqrt{2}i$, $-\sqrt{2}i$, $\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i)$, $\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i)$, $\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i)$, and $\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i)$.

You are given a sequence of 12 complex numbers $z(j)$ for $j$ from $1$ to $12$ inclusive, such that each $z(j)$ is an element of $V$. Let $P$ be the product of these 12 numbers.

If $P = -1$ and the cardinality of the set $A$ intersected with the set of natural numbers such that $P = -1$ is 233 times the cardinality of $A$, find the solution.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and V :: "complex set" 
and p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and j :: nat
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1/sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> (P j \<in> V \<and> p j = P j)"
and h2 : "prod p {1..12} = -1"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and V :: "complex set" 
and p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and j :: nat
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1/sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1/sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> (P j \<in> V \<and> p j = P j)"
and h2 : "prod p {1..12} = -1"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Given a set V which contains the complex numbers $\sqrt{2}i, -\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1+\i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{-1+\i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{1-\i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{-1-\i}{\sqrt{8}}$. 

Also, we know that for all natural numbers j from 1 to 12, $P(j)$ is a member of set V and $p(j) = P(j)$. 

The product of $p(j)$ for all j from 1 to 12 equals -1. 

Find the values of a, b, and p that satisfy the equation $a + b + p = 233$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines V_def: "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, -sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and z_def: "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and P_def: "P \<equiv> prod (\<lambda> j. z j) {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "P = -1"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
where "a :: nat" "b :: nat" "p :: nat" "prime p" "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes V :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
defines V_def: "V \<equiv> {sqrt 2 * \<i>, -sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and z_def: "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and P_def: "P \<equiv> prod (\<lambda> j. z j) {1..12}"
assumes h0 : "P = -1"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
where "a :: nat" "b :: nat" "p :: nat" "prime p" "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Given a set V of complex numbers that includes $\sqrt{2}i$, $-\sqrt{2}i$, and $\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}$ times each of $1+i$, $-1+i$, $1-i$, and $-1-i$. Assume that there is a sequence of 12 complex numbers $z_j$, for $1 \leq j \leq 12$, where each $z_j$ is an element of V. Define P as the product of all the $z_j$'s from $j = 1$ to $j = 12$, and assume that $P = -1$.

Find three natural numbers a, b, and p such that $a + b + p = 233$, p is prime, and $a \mod p \neq 0$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "P = -1"
shows  "let a = 2; b = 6; p = 3 in a + b + p = 233"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and P :: complex
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "P = -1"
shows  "let a = 2; b = 6; p = 3 in a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: We have a set $V$ that contains six elements: $\sqrt 2i$, $-\sqrt 2i$, $\frac{1+\iota}{\sqrt 8}$, $\frac{-1+\iota}{\sqrt 8}$, $\frac{1-\iota}{\sqrt 8}$, $\frac{-1-\iota}{\sqrt 8}$. We also have a sequence $z$ of 12 terms, each of which is an element of $V$. We define a complex number $P$ as the product of all terms in the sequence $z$. We know that $P = -1$. The goal is to show that for $a = 2$, $b = 6$, and $p = 3$, the sum $a + b + p$ equals 233.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and prob :: "complex \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> P"
and h2 : "prob (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j) = a / p powr b"
and h3 : "p > 1 \<and> is_prime p \<and> a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex set" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and prob :: "complex \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, - sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 + \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (1 - \<i>), 1 / sqrt 8 * (-1 - \<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> P"
and h2 : "prob (\<Prod>j = 1..12. z j) = a / p powr b"
and h3 : "p > 1 \<and> is_prime p \<and> a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A complex number $z_j$ is chosen randomly from the set $P = \{i \sqrt{2}, -i \sqrt{2}, \frac{1+i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{-1+i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{1-i}{\sqrt{8}}, \frac{-1-i}{\sqrt{8}}\}$ for each integer $j$ from $1$ to $12$. The probability of the product of these twelve numbers being a certain complex number is given as $\frac{a}{p^b}$, where $p > 1$ is a prime number, and $a$ is not a multiple of $p$. Find the value of $a + b + p$. The final answer is $233$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes V :: "complex set"
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
and P :: complex
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, -sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1/sqrt 8*(1+\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(-1+\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(1-\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(-1-\<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j=1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "prob {P. P = -1} = a / p powr b"
and h4 : "prime p"
and h5 : "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The vertices $V$ of a centrally symmetric hexagon in the complex plane are given by \[V=\left\{   \sqrt{2}i,-\sqrt{2}i, \frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1+i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(1-i),\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}(-1-i) \right\}.\]For each $j$, $1\leq j\leq 12$, an element $z_j$ is chosen from $V$ at random, independently of the other choices. Let $P={\prod}_{j=1}^{12}z_j$ be the product of the $12$ numbers selected.

The probability that $P=-1$ can be expressed in the form
\[\frac{a}{p^b},\]where $a,$ $b,$ $p$ are positive integers, $p$ is prime, and $a$ is not divisible by $p.$  Find $a + b + p.$ The final Answer is 233
 ### Proof
 The first two vertices of $V$ have magnitude $\sqrt{2}$, while the other four have magnitude $\dfrac{1}{2}$. In order for $P=-1$, it must be the case that $|P|=1$, which only happens if there are two magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices for each magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ one.
 Define $P_1$ as the product of the magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ vertices chosen and $P_2$ as the product of the magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices chosen. There are $\dbinom{12}{8}$ ways to select which of the 12 draws come up with a magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ number.
 The arguments of those numbers are all $\pm\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_1$ has an argument that is a multiple of $\pi$. Half of the $2^8$ draw sequences will produce a result with argument equivalent to $0$ and the other half will have an argument equivalent to $\pi$.
 Similarly, the arguments of the other four numbers are $\dfrac{\pi}{4}+k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, so $P_2$ has argument $k\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ for some integer $k$. The $4^4$ ways to select four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ numbers are equally likely to produce any of the four possible product arguments.
 In order for $P=-1$, the argument of the product must be $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$. That happens only if: (a) $P_1$ has argument $0$ and $P_2$ has argument $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.
 (b) $P_2$ has argument $\pi$ and $P_2$ has argument $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, which also happens with probability $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{1}{8}$. Putting these cases together, we find that $\dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{1}{8}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the $2^8\cdot 4^4=2^{16}$ sequences of eight magnitude-$\sqrt{2}$ and four magnitude-$\dfrac{1}{2}$ vertices will have the correct argument for $P=-1$.
 The probability that $P=-1$ is \begin{align}   \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot 2^{16}}{6^{12}} &= \dfrac{\dbinom{12}{4}4}{3^{12}} \\    &= \dfrac{12\cdot 11\cdot 10\cdot 9\cdot 4}{4!\cdot 3^{12}} \\
    &= \dfrac{220}{3^{10}}. \\ \end{align}The final answer is $220 + 3 + 10 = \boxed{233}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes V :: "complex set"
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
and P :: complex
assumes h0 : "V = {sqrt 2 * \<i>, -sqrt 2 * \<i>, 1/sqrt 8*(1+\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(-1+\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(1-\<i>), 1/sqrt 8*(-1-\<i>)}"
and h1 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> z j \<in> V"
and h2 : "P = (\<Prod>j=1..12. z j)"
and h3 : "prob {P. P = -1} = a / p powr b"
and h4 : "prime p"
and h5 : "a mod p \<noteq> 0"
shows  "a + b + p = 233"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a set $V$ which includes $\sqrt{2}i$, $-\sqrt{2}i$, $\frac{1+\i}{\sqrt{8}}$, $\frac{-1+\i}{\sqrt{8}}$, $\frac{1-\i}{\sqrt{8}}$, and $\frac{-1-\i}{\sqrt{8}}$. There is a sequence $z_j$ for $1 \leq j \leq 12$ with each $z_j \in V$. Define $P$ as the product of all $z_j$ from $j=1$ to $j=12$. If the probability that $P = -1$ is represented as $\frac{a}{p^b}$, where $p$ is a prime number and $a$ is not divisible by $p$, find the value of $a + b + p$. The final answer is 233.
